div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, January 23, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: NORDDEUTSCHER LLOYD
div.p: BREMEN.

EXPRESS MAIL STEAMERS
FROM

TO

BREMEN, HAMBURG, AMERICA,

For Particulars see Advertisement below.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Pacific Line of Royal Mail Steamers.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARDS to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Orient" will leave Suez about January 26
R.M.S "Orontez" will leave Suez about February 9.
HOMEWARDS to NAPLES MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY
R.M.S. "Orotava" will leave Port Said about January 29
R.M.S. “Ormux" will leave Port Said about February 12
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 8 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all information apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT-SAID & PORT-TEWFIK (Suez) 31-12-904

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL STEAMERS.
div.p: Special Reduced Rates During Summer Season,
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,635 tons, leaves about February 1.
S.S. Lancashire 4,244 tons, leaves about February 5.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,160 tons, leaves about February 15.
S.S. Shropshire 4,196 tons leaves about February 19.

Agents Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Saturday, January 27, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

S.S. ARRACAN 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about February 15 for Liverpool
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.

Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about January 17 and January 31. To Aden, Karachi, and Bombay accelerated service about January 14. To Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about January 28.
East African Line.
To Aden, Mombassa, Zanzibar, Beira, Delagoa Bay, Durban, about July 4 and January 22.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arrangements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
HENRI CHAMOULLEAU, Proprietor.

GHEZIREH PALACE HOTEL. On the bank of the Nile. Formerly the Palace of the Khedive Ismail Transformed into a luxurious hotel. SPLENDID PARK. Renowned for its afternoon-teas on the West Balcony overlooking the Park. Excellent Tsigane Orchestra. Motor-car running to Shepheard’s Hotel and vice-versa. 26737-3l-3-906

div.head: Tewfik Palace Hotel.
div.p: Helouan, near Cairo.

Formerly the favourite Residence of H.H. the Khedive. Perfect Sanitation.–Purest Desert air. Electric Light. Hot and old baths attached to most rooms. House warmed by special system of Radiators, adjoining the Golf Links and Race Course, Tennis, Billiards, Garden and open air palm house, good stabling , dark room. Excellent Table. Moderate Charges.
Medical Resident Director: Arthur J.M. Bentley, M.D. –Town Office at Stephenson & Co., Opera Square, Cairo.
26 56-31-3-908 P.E HERGEL, MANAGER

div.head: GRAND CONTINENTAL HOTEL
div.p: Open all the year. Unrivalled position in centre of Cairo, opposite Khedivial Opera House and Esbekieh Gardens. Magnificent Verandah, French Restaurant and Grill-room, Bars and Billiard Saloons open to non-residents. Supper after the theatre.
GEORGE NUNGOVICH HOTELS
PREVENTS THE ATTACK OF MOSQUITOES.
Beetham's "Larola"
Will entirely Remove all ROUGHNESS, REDNESS, HEAT, IRRITATION, &c., in a very short time. IT KEEPS THE SKIN SOFT, SMOOTH, AND WHITE at all seasons, and is DELIGHTFULLY COOLING and REFRESHING.
Agent: MAX FISCHER, CAIRO and ALEXANDRIA.
Sole Makers M. BEETHAM & SON, CHELTENHAM, ENGLAND

div.head: Thomas & Sons
div.p: SPORTING TAILORS & BREECHES MAKERS
32, BROOK STREET, LONDON, W.
SHOOTING, HUNTING, and FISHING SPECIALTIES.
RACING, POLO and MUFTI BREECHES of every Description.

Thomas & Sons' representative, Mr. E.L. Botham, is now in Egypt for the Cairo Season and will be glad to receive orders for either sporting or ordinary clothes to be executed at their London establishment and fitted in Egypt.
Addresses: Hotel Metropole, Cairo; Hotel Abbat, Alexandria.
THOMAS & SONS, 32, BROOK STREET, W.
Telegrams: Sportingly, London.

div.head:
IMPORTANT NOTICE.
MARTELL COGNAC.
div.p: M. H. DEMIRGIAN BEY, General Agent for this important House, warns the public to beware of Imitations, and to examine the labels, corks, and capsules.
The principal importers of this well-known Brand are
At Alexandria: MM. G. Attard & Co. Christo C. Solea, Costi H. Georgiou, N. Pappa, A. & G. Monferato, John B. Caffari, Frangini Mitzos & Co. Cokinos Freres, P, J. Zombos.
At Cairo: MM. S. di M. Riso, A. Jeronymidis & John B.Caffari.
Where customers will find the genuine MARTELLI, which cannot be sold below the minimum price given below for each quality:
* 35/- per case or P.T. 170.5.
VO 53/- per case or P.T. 256.
All so-called MARTELL Cognacs sold below these prices cannot be genuine.
The Egyptian Gazette The English Daily Newspaper , Established 1830 and Manager R. Snelling Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF. TUESDAY, JANUARY 23, 1906

MOROCCO ANU ABYSSINIA One of the many writers on Africa said some years ago, that throughout the continent, from North to South, there exists some subtle climatic influence which, acting on human nerves, tends to make the people very quarrel - soma This is said to apply not Only to natives, but more particularly to foreigners. It is, we thick, admitted that the experience of recent years has quite justified this opinion, by along series of events still so freshly before us that it is not necessary to recapitulate them. The disputed question of most immediate importance is that of Morocco. This question has loomed largely before os for many month’, but it is. probably,, now only a matter of days before some of the results of the Conference of Algesiras will be known to the world. Already there rooms to be a general opinion that although this question has given rise to a good deal of anxiety, an amicable settlement will probably be arrived at We sincerely hope that this will be so, sad we should have been still more pleased if we could have looked forward to the future with a sigh of relief at . the idea that African questions bad subsided fora while But,however s satisfactory may be the news we all anxiously await from Algesiras. we regret to say that it may not be long before another African question became* acute, and this time if will interest Egypt more nearly than does the question of Morocco. We refer to Abyssinia. For the last twelve years a question has been brewing there which "pro¬mises to result in a very considerable crop of internatioral difficulties It all began with what would appear at first sight to be almost simple- matter, which, in view of the serious complica¬tions likely to arise from it, merits some in 1893, some friends of the Emperor Menelik expressed the wish to make a railway for him from the Red Sea to hit capital. Hitherto most of the Abyssinian exports were taken in a clumsy sort of way by caravan to the port of Zaila in British Somaliland, for our readers will remember that one of the difficulties of Abyssinian development is that it has no sea. coast of its own, and it results from many rather cunningly devised international arrangements that Menelik has to pass through foreign territory, either French, British, or Italian, before he can get to any ports It might appear to some people that after the successful war which England waged against Abyssinia some, forty years ago, the British Government might have secured this exclusive advantage, for the expedition had been a ‘costly one ; bat so far as we can re¬member the principal result has been that an English nobleman takes his title from the then capital of Abyssinia. We cannot remember exactly what constituted the French title to their part of Somaliland, but at all events they have it, and it includes the port of Djibouti. In 1893 Menelik’s friends were French or acting in French interests, and it naturally occurred to them that it would be a good thing to make a railway from Djibouti, and thus take away the trade, with its large prospect of future development, from Zaila. The line would then pass for a distance of about 50 miles through French territory. Although this line was expressly intended to be a purely commercial undertaking, and Menelik was naturally anxious to secure the advantages of development which it would open out, he was still cautious enough stipulate that he would wait and see how he got on with his new friends and their railway as far as Harrar, or not quite half way from the sea to his capital, before he gave them any permission to take their line on to Adis Abeba. Subsequent events have shown that be was exceedingly well advised. It would take us much beyond the limits of this article to trace the interesting development of this railway question ; we intend to return to it again in a few days in greater detoil. For the moment we will only summarise in a few words the facts that, as is not unusual in similar undertakings, the railway company got into financial difficulties, the line cost more than was expected it always does,— the company being French, had naturally to appeal to the French Government to get it out of its difficulties, .long negotiations follow- el, ending in the whole thing being entirely converted from a commercial into a political undertaking, and this, "mirabile dicta,”.with¬out it being considered necessary to consult t Menelik about it in any way. Later on the" somewhat meagre funds allotted by the French Government were exhausted, and a New African Company and a New Egyptian Company had to be called to the rescue. Still later Menelik became so disgusted with the conduct of his. friends, that in May, 1905, he convened the representatives of the four European Powers principally interested, and told them very plainly what he thought about the action of the railway company, and added that if be did not very shortly receive some much more reasonable proposals he would make the line himself from Harrar on to hie capital at Adis Abeba' a distance of about 300 miles. Although the “entente eordiale” ‘between England and France did not refer to Abyssiuis we still think that it- would have been of much assistance in bringing matters to an understanding if the question had been I ft to the only Governments much interested in it until quite recently ; we mean those of France, England, and Italy, but unfortunately Germany has now appeared on the scene, and after the not very successful mission of Dr Rosen, is sending a Minister to the Court of the Emperor Menelik, probably with the laudable wish of taking advantage of the rivalries of the other nations. In spite of the rather cool reception he got from. Menelik, Dr. Rosen is said to be determined to acquire commercial equality in Abyssinia, and to assist in the establishment of trade communi-cations between that country and the coast. He apparently does not consider the fact that these communications must necessarily be made through either French, British, or Italian terri¬tory to be of much importance. We must say that we feel much sympathy with the Ethiopeans monarch in his struggles with civilisation, and if he wishes to make his railway line himself, vhy should he not be allowed to do so. if he cau And perhaps now that fie has a Bank, he may be able- to raise the necessary funds.
